title: Log the HTTP status code for GitLab for Jira App
description:
## Description

Based on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/379675#note_1194791839, we want to add logging for the HTTP status code, so we may learn more about the cause of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352411+.

title: Moving tooltip of the filter items to the side instead of the top
description: This suggestion will affect the following filters: - image filter - tool filter (for disabled state) | Current | Proposal | | ------ | ------ | | ![image](/uploads/609c81413b33d6e4ffb2ca353962f31d/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/043e5fa390d63aa8626cc6bbb23f1a26/image.png) | The following discussion from !105417 should be addressed: - [ ] @dftian started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/105417#note_1193910222): (+2 comments) > Currently, the tooltip can show above or below the item, has quite a long delay, and the tooltip arrow is centered in the middle of the dropdown item rather than the text, which can have it pointing to empty space: > > ![Peek_2022-12-01_22-16](/uploads/7235df17e6bbc442a4d5ade07d002156/Peek_2022-12-01_22-16.mp4) > > I think that it'll look better if we have it show on the left (with auto-flip to the right side if it can't fit) and remove the delay so the user knows right away why it's disabled: > > ![Peek_2022-12-01_22-19](/uploads/6d767927adf57759b0d8c1dc42a747a9/Peek_2022-12-01_22-19.mp4) > > 3. With the above change, the tooltip config will match what the image filter tooltip does, so we can switch it to use the `tooltip` property. > > ```patch > Subject: [PATCH] clipboard > --- > Index: ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/filter_item.vue > IDEA additional info: > Subsystem: com.intellij.openapi.diff.impl.patch.CharsetEP > <+>UTF-8 > =================================================================== > diff --git a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/filter_item.vue b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/filter_item.vue > --- a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/filter_item.vue (revision 3202ef83ccfe190a03fbf0ab0215d3507b11eadc) > +++ b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/filter_item.vue (date 1669969287020) > @@ -3,9 +3,7 @@ > > export default { > components: { GlDropdownItem }, > - directives: { > - GlTooltip, > - }, > + directives: { GlTooltip }, > props: { > isChecked: { > type: Boolean, > @@ -32,26 +30,31 @@ > return `filter_${this.text.toLowerCase().replace(' ', '_')}_dropdown`; > }, > }, > + methods: { > + emitClick() { > + if (!this.disabled) { > + this.$emit('click'); > + } > + }, > + }, > }; > > > > ```

title: Follow-up: Update image filter to use the tooltip prop
description:
In this MR > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/105417, tooltip support is added to the FilterItem component. So let's update the image filter component to use this instead of its own tooltip settings.

```diff
Index: ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/image_filter.vue
IDEA additional info:
Subsystem: com.intellij.openapi.diff.impl.patch.CharsetEP
<+>UTF-8
===================================================================
diff --git a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/image_filter.vue b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/image_filter.vue
--- a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/image_filter.vue	(revision 3202ef83ccfe190a03fbf0ab0215d3507b11eadc)
+++ b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/image_filter.vue	(date 1669969358696)
@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
 <script>
-import { GlTruncate, GlTooltipDirective as GlTooltip } from '@gitlab/ui';
+import { GlTruncate } from '@gitlab/ui';
 import { createAlert } from '~/flash';
 import agentImagesQuery from 'ee/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/agent_images.query.graphql';
 import projectImagesQuery from 'ee/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/project_images.query.graphql';
@@ -11,7 +11,6 @@
 
 export default {
   components: { FilterBody, FilterItem, GlTruncate },
-  directives: { GlTooltip },
   extends: SimpleFilter,
   apollo: {
     images: {
@@ -91,7 +90,7 @@
     <filter-item
       v-for="option in images"
       :key="option.id"
-      v-gl-tooltip.left.viewport="option.id"
+      :tooltip="option.id"
       :is-checked="isSelected(option)"
       @click="toggleOption(option)"
     >
```

title: Follow-up: Update spec to use"trigger" for cluster filter
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/104777#note_1194317723


> `ee/spec/frontend/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/cluster_filter_spec.js`
> ```diff
> - findDropdownItem(name).vm.$emit('click');
> + findDropdownItem(name).trigger('click');
> ```
> 
> *suggestion*: I think we could use `trigger` here, which I think has the benefit of being closer to the browser.
> 
> For example as-is, this particular spec would still pass even if the click handler in `filter_item.vue` isn't set up emit a Vue \`click' event. Or if the select item was disabled.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `limit_assigned_issues_count`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

<!--
Set the main issue link: The main issue is the one that describes the problem to solve,
the one this feature flag is being added for. For example:

[main-issue]: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/123456
-->

[main-issue]: MAIN-ISSUE-LINK

## Summary

This issue is to rollout the assigned issues count limit (!105759) on production,
that is currently behind the `limit_assigned_issues_count` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::project management" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_project-management`, `#s_plan`
- Best individual to reach out to: @euko, @donaldcook 
- PM: @gweaver

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Set a milestone to the rollout issue to signal for enabling and removing the feature flag when it is stable.
- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing estimated time when this feature flag will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

<!-- A feature flag can also be used for rolling out a bug fix or a maintenance work.
In this scenario, labels must be related to it, for example; ~"type::feature", ~"type::bug" or ~"type::maintenance".
Please use /copy_metadata to copy the labels from the issue you're rolling out. -->

title: Updating webhook via API removes secret token value
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When [creating a project hook](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#add-project-hook) you can optionally provide a `token` parameter and value to define a secret token for the webhook. 

If you then [edit that hook](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#edit-project-hook) via the API, the secret token is erased, even if no `token` parameter was provided. This means you must now provide a `token` parameter and value each time you edit a webhook, or you risk losing that value entirely. 

This was reported by a [Premium customer](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/350244) who states this only recently started occurring. I can confirm that this does not occur on a self-managed installation running 15.2.0. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. In a test project of your choosing, add a project hook [via the API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#add-project-hook). Be sure to provide a `token` parameter and value. 
2. Navigate to the webhook via project settings >> webhooks. Click the "edit" button on the webhook you created, and observe the populated "Secret token" field. 
3. Note the webhook ID from the URL and use this value to [edit the webhook via the API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#edit-project-hook). Do not provide the `token` parameter. 
4. Navigate back to the webhook and note the "Secret token" field has been stripped. 

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The "secret token" value is removed from webhooks when updated via the API.  

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The "secret token" value is not removed from the webhook unless you specifically include an empty `token` parameter value you in your request. 


### Output of checks

<!-- If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, uncomment below -->

This bug happens on GitLab.com
### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

![image](/uploads/f81d5e7f0ab7b387ef84b290890e31fa/image.png)

Let's make the following improvements:
* Add the required scope (`api` and `read_repository`) to the text.
* Change the wording and advise users to consider an expiration date according to the size of the migration

 vulnerabilities/findings. We need to adjust this read operation after removal of `Vulnerabilities::Feedback` so that we do not depend on feedback model anymore when `deprecate_vulnerabilities_feedback` FF is on. This preloader is currently used in two places:

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### Cleaning up the feature flag

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

### Availability and Testing

Please ensure `e2e:package-and-test` job passes in the MR that removes the feature flag. Feel free to reach out to the SET (@a_mcdonald) for assistance.

title: Update FedRamp PAT creation to be an Application setting or via API
description:
As part of FedRamp requirements, PAT creation was disabled for FIPs enabled instances using `Gitlab::FIPS.enabled` in the MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97299+ The 2FA bypass (& therefore PAT disabling) is a FedRamp requirement and as such not directly needed by FIPs where certain deployments may be running on FIPs node and still need tokens for automation.  


The proposal https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/384110+ suggests to uncouple PAT creation from the flag `Gitlab::FIPS.enabled` onto an application setting or via an API.

Get tag signature via API
description:
### Release notes

Get tag signature via API.

Currently, the UI shows the verification status of tags, but there is no way to fetch it over the API, as far as I could tell. For commits there is `GET /projects/:id/repository/commits/:sha/signature`. I want equivalent functionality for tags. Something like `GET /api/v4/projects/:id/repository/tags/:name/signature`.

### Problem to solve

Every user can configure their keys to make GitLab's verification of the tags accurate. It doesn't seem feasible to duplicate this verification locally, so there is no way for automation to know if a tag has a valid signature or not.

### Proposal

Add new API endpoint, `GET /api/v4/projects/:id/repository/tags/:name/signature`, that behaves like `GET /projects/:id/repository/commits/:sha/signature` does for commits. cf. https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/commits.html#get-gpg-signature-of-a-commit

### Intended users

Used by anyone who automates CICD operations. The capability to verify tag signatures can be used to harden audit trails trails and increase
trust in any information stored in tags, which increases GitOps security.

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)

### Feature Usage Metrics

You can track the usage of the feature by tracking how often the API endpoint is called.

title: Upgrade DAST HSQLDB integration tests
description:
Follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/merge_requests/667#note_1187342839

## Problem to solve

DAST and ZAP are currently using HSQLDB 2.7.1 [zap_database.py#L13](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/src/zap_gateway/zap_database/zap_database.py#L13) but the test for this code uses HSQLDB 2.5.0.

Simply updating [test_zap_database.py#L12](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L12) to use HSQLDB 2.7.1 or even 2.5.2 does not work as [test_can_retrieve_inserted_values](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L15) and [`test_can_reconnect_to_a_closed_database`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L55) both fail.

This does NOT mean that DAST is broken. During a scan, DAST connects and reads from the ZAP HSQLDB session which is tested in the e2e tests and [`test_can_read_zap_database`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L29) which continues to work.

At present, it seems that the issue could lie in initializing a new database through [jaydebeapi](https://github.com/baztian/jaydebeapi) but this is unconfirmed. The library has not been updated for some time and changes in HSQLDB might not have been reflected in this plugin. This needs further investigation. 

Note: changing [`_database`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/src/zap_gateway/zap_database/zap_database.py#L72) to return the database file name rather than the database name causes [test_zap_database.py#L12](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L12) to pass but breaks the other tests and the e2e tests.

Code that causes [test_zap_database.py#L12](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/blob/bc4911b0317b5cf556f5c1898aeddd3c7dbdf0d6/test/integration/test_zap_database.py#L12) to pass

```python
    def _database(self) -> str:
        database = path.join(self._database_dir, f'{Settings.SESSION_NAME}.session')
        data_file = f'{database}.data'

        if not path.exists(data_file):
            raise RuntimeError(f'Failed to find ZAP database {data_file}')
        return data_file #updated from database
```

### Options

1) Upgrade the integration test to HSQLDB 2.7.1 and delete the failing tests, as DAST does not create its own database. The risk here is that a subsequent ZAP and HSQLDB upgrade might stop DAST from connecting to the database at all. At that point, we'll need to address this issue.
2) Continue investigation, possibly forking https://github.com/baztian/jaydebeapi if an issue is found.

description:
This issue was created from this discussion https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/103478#note_1188819341.

`ChatNames::FindUserService` has been changed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/103478 to not necessarily need an `Integration` to find the `ChatName` record. The integration is always irrelevant (related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/357221) and we should refactor the class to not take an integration.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `ci_enable_debug_first_trace`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout updating debug_trace_enabled for the [first trace being sent](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/104945)
on production, that is currently behind the `ci_enable_debug_first_trace` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::pipeline execution"
- Most appropriate Slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline_execution`
- Best individual to reach out to: @morefice
- PM:

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

We should to update build metadata only once.

### What are we expecting to happen?

We update build metadata for each trace being sent.

### When is the feature viable?

```ruby
Feature.enable(:ci_enable_debug_first_trace)
```

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Query time and error rate increase.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects
(302 HTTP response status)_

- https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-pipeline_execution/stage-groups-pipeline-execution-group-dashboard?orgId=1

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
  - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
  - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_enable_debug_first_trace true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
  - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
  - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_enable_debug_first_trace true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` Slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's Slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_enable_debug_first_trace <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_enable_debug_first_trace <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_enable_debug_first_trace true`
- [ ] Announce on [#f_ci_time_decay](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C02P0FZLQMD) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `ci_enable_debug_first_trace` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
  - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
  - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
  - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
  - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
  - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_enable_debug_first_trace --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set ci_enable_debug_first_trace false
```

title: Provide visual hint that Web IDE search is limited to open files
description:
### Problem

During the beta release the search in the new Web IDE will only take all opened files into account. As this is a big limitation and severe difference to what users are used to in both local IDEs as well as competitor product that have browser IDEs, we need to somehow make this limitation clear in the UI.

title: Make clear that projects are migrated with groups
description:
### Problem

Docs and UI do not clearly state that projects are migrated with groups with GitLab Migration.

User feedback:

> Anyway to give you a direct feedback, the current gitlab UI indicates that projects are migrated via "Create Project" -> "import Project" -> "Import from Gitlab Export" and groups are being migrated by "Create Group" -> "Import Group". The documentation is also a little bit confusing since the Automate group and project import section is referencing the congregate tool which we can't use as non admins. When I went through the documentation it was not clear to me that "Import Group" is also able to migrate projects. This could be stated clearer in the UI and the documentation.

### Proposed solution

- [x] Adjust documentation in all necessary places.
- [ ] We could add a sentence "When migrating a top-level group to GitLab.com, all its subgroups and projects are migrated too." to UI on the page: 
![Screen_Shot_2022-12-19_at_11.24.46](/uploads/153c0dd7a5031212b9b9d267b539a9e1/Screen_Shot_2022-12-19_at_11.24.46.png)

or wait for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/385689+ to be done, as then the fact of importing projects with groups should be clear enough.

Wdyt @chrismicek @xanf @wortschi?

Related issue for adding affordance in UI: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383755+.

title: GitLab Migration - an invalid request to start a new migration results in error 500
description:
From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/import/discussions/-/issues/30#note_1184728696

An invalid request to start a new migration via API is usually raising an exception and results in a 500 error returned to the user. We should return the actual error back to the user instead.

E.g. if you pass an invalid token - user sees `500 Internal Server Error` but the real error is `Unsuccessful response 401 from /api/v4/metadata. Body: {"message"=>"401 Unauthorized"})`

### Proposed solution

Rescuing BulkImports::NetworkError [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/41a9effce22f0b3cc800130ba277a66db55f7a78/app/services/bulk_imports/create_service.rb#L46) should fix the issue.

epic.title: Release migrating GitLab projects with groups by direct transfer to open beta

title: GitLab Migration - If you enter a bad url + token the error message is not shown on the status page
description:
From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/import/discussions/-/issues/30#note_1182731002

If you enter a bad url + token the error message is not shown on the status page. It's only shown to you when you go back AND refresh the page. Can be quite confusing for a user.

![GLMerrors.mp4](/uploads/3cf71d94442641263ae46b805b3fd68f/GLMerrors.mp4.mp4)

* if you enter a bad url (e.g. https://not_existed_url.com), you'll see the `Host cannot be resolved or invalid` error and won't be redirected to `{{host}}/import/bulk_imports/status`
* if you enter any existing URL other than GitLab source URL (e.g. - https://www.google.com/, https://some.website), you'll be redirected to `{{host}}/import/bulk_imports/status` page and won't see any errors until you refresh this page (or until you go back and refresh the page)

As @krisberry [pointed out](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9285#note_1191515119), it might behave the same for expired tokens (which the user still treats as valid) and might be frustrating for the user.

title: curl examples in GitLab migration doc are missing content-type header
description:
### Problem

Our API docs example to [start a new migration](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/bulk_imports.html#start-a-new-gitlab-migration) does not work. If example is used the error message is returned: `"error":"configuration is missing` even if configuration is missing.

The reason is a missing `Content-Type: application/json` header.

### Proposal
Let's update our documentation and add the missing info:

```diff
curl --request POST --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: <your_access_token>" "https://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/bulk_imports" \
+ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
  --data '{
    "configuration": {
      "url": "http://gitlab.example/",
      "access_token": "access_token"
    },
    "entities": [
      {
        "source_full_path": "source/full/path",
        "source_type": "group_entity",
        "destination_slug": "destination_slug",
        "destination_namespace": "destination/namespace/path"
      }
    ]
  }'
```

We should probably include it in all of our docs.

title: Remove `container_repository_updated_event_id` column from geo_event_log table
description:
According to [3-milestone column drop procedure](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/avoiding_downtime_in_migrations.html#dropping-columns) we need 3 step process. This issue is for step 2 - "Dropping the column (release M+1)".
The first step is completed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96419#note_1181718552

In the scope of this issue, we need to: 
- [x] Remove `container_repository_updated_event_id` column from `geo_event_log` table
- [x] Remove `geo_container_repository_updated_events` table with all the constraints and indices
- [x] Create an issue for step 3 (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/386702)

Migrations:

**db/post_migrate/20220826152430_remove_container_repository_deprecated_geo_fields.rb**
```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

class RemoveContainerRepositoryDeprecatedGeoFields < Gitlab::Database::Migration[2.0]
  disable_ddl_transaction!

  def up
    with_lock_retries do
      remove_column :geo_event_log, :container_repository_updated_event_id, :bigint
    end
  end

  def down
    with_lock_retries do
      unless column_exists?(:geo_event_log, :container_repository_updated_event_id)
        add_column(:geo_event_log, :container_repository_updated_event_id, :bigint)
      end
    end

    add_concurrent_foreign_key :geo_event_log, :geo_container_repository_updated_events,
                               column: :container_repository_updated_event_id,
                               name: 'fk_6ada82d42a',
                               on_delete: :cascade

    add_concurrent_index :geo_event_log,
                         :container_repository_updated_event_id,
                         name: 'index_geo_event_log_on_container_repository_updated_event_id'
  end
end
```

**db/post_migrate/20220826152432_remove_container_repository_updated_events.rb**

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

class RemoveContainerRepositoryUpdatedEvents < Gitlab::Database::Migration[2.0]
  disable_ddl_transaction!

  def up
    drop_table :geo_container_repository_updated_events
  end

  def down
    create_table :geo_container_repository_updated_events, id: :bigserial do |t|
      t.integer :container_repository_id,
        null: false,
        index: { name: :idx_geo_con_rep_updated_events_on_container_repository_id }
    end

    add_concurrent_foreign_key :geo_container_repository_updated_events, :container_repositories,
                               column: :container_repository_id,
                               name: 'fk_212c89c706',
                               on_delete: :cascade
  end
end
```

title: Display appropriate error message when Gitaly is unavailable
description:
We are using GraphQL [custom error codes](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/apollo-server/data/errors/#custom-errors) to provide extra easy parsable details to the front end. They have been implemented for the `paginatedTree` type resolver https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/104696#3a5cd4ee0f385e6d4aeef40ae8dad6e40e4f3bda.

The goal is to display an error message that makes it clear that gitaly is unavailable in the UI instead of the generic one.

**How to set up and validate locally**
1. `gdk start`
1. go to http://127.0.0.1:3000/flightjs/Flight
1. `gdk stop gitaly`
1. reload the page with inspector should see details about the error that are easy for the FE to handle in the extensions field.

title: Exec Dashboards: Add tooltips and drill-down links to the metrics names.
description:
## [Overview](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370887)

Related to this [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381787#note_1180448224). 

## Problem to solve

In order to understand what is affecting the team performance, user need more information and context about how the metrics are calculated.

## Proposal 

1. Add tooltips to the metrics names. 
2. The tooltip will have description about how the metric is calculated. 
3. The tooltip will have [link to drill-down](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/382027) from each metric to a report with in-depth data. 
4. The tooltip will also have a link to the docs.
5. Mouseover on the metric name will show the tooltip. 
 Example from the VSA tiles tooltips:

![Screen_Shot_2022-11-24_at_13.08.07](/uploads/96ee580968f758a8cafd9ee6ade761c5/Screen_Shot_2022-11-24_at_13.08.07.png)

### Tooltips description:

| # | Metric name             | Description                                                                                                                                       | Drill down for deeper insights                                                                                     | Go to Docs                                                                                                         |
|---|-------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1 | Deployment Frequency    | Average number of deployments to production per day. This metric measures how often value is delivered to end users.                                       | https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/ci_cd?tab=deployment-frequency                                    | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/dora_metrics.html#deployment-frequency                                   |
| 2 | Lead Time for Changes   | The time to successfully deliver a commit into production. This metric reflects the efficiency of CI/CD pipelines. | https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/ci_cd?tab=lead-time                                               | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/dora_metrics.html#lead-time-for-changes                                  |
| 3 | Time to Restore Service | The time it takes an organization to recover from a failure in production.                                       | https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/ci_cd?tab=time-to-restore-service                                 | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/dora_metrics.html#time-to-restore-service                                |
| 4 | Change Failure Rate     | Percentage of deployments that cause an incident in production.                                                                                   | https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/ci_cd?tab=change-failure-rate                                     | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/dora_metrics.html#change-failure-rate                                    |
| 5 | VSA Lead Time           | Median time from issue created to issue closed.                                                                                                   |  https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics                                           | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/value_stream_analytics.html#view-the-lead-time-and-cycle-time-for-issues |
| 6 | VSA Cycle Time          | Median time from the earliest commit of a linked issue's merge request to when that issue is closed.                                              | https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics                                            | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/value_stream_analytics.html#view-the-lead-time-and-cycle-time-for-issues |
| 7 | New Issues              | Number of new issues created.                                                                                                                     |  https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/issues_analytics                                                           | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/issue_analytics.html                                                     |
| 8 | Number of Deploys       | Total number of deploys to production.                                                                                                            | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/analytics/merge_request_analytics?start_date=2021-11-24&end_date=2022-11-24 | https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/merge_request_analytics.html                                             |
  
1. Drill-down inherent the sub-groups / projects.
1. Out of scope - inherent labels and time period.

title: [Feature flag] Cleanup `:schema_linting`
description:
## Summary

This issue is to cleanup the `schema_linting` feature flag, after the feature flag has been enabled by default for an appropriate amount of time in production.

## Owners

- Team: Create::Editor
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_editor`
- Best individual to reach out to: @dmishunov 
- PM: @ericschurter 

## Stakeholders

## Expectations

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

### Cleaning up the feature flag

* [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
  * [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
  * [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
  * [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
* [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary. If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1), the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
  * [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
* [x] Close the feature issue to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
* [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
* [x] Close this rollout issue.

title: Trigger mergeRequestApprovalStateUpdated subscription when approval is given, revoked or reset
description:
### Problem to solve

The merge request approval widget shows different state when:

- MR is approved
- MR is was unapproved
- All approvals of MR was reset (e.g. reset on push)

Whenever these scenarios happen, we want to update the approval widget in real-time to show updated state.

### Proposal

Trigger the `mergeRequestApprovalStateUpdated` when the scenarios above occurs so ~frontend will be able to show the updated merge status on merge widget.

We can trigger the subscription in `MergeRequests::ApprovalService`, `MergeRequests::RemoveApprovalService` and `MergeRequests::BaseService#reset_approvals`.

title: Document the "allow anyone option" option for the package registry
description:
## :deciduous_tree: Context

The package registry visibility and permissions usually work by following the project visibility. A private project will host a private package registry.

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329253, we are introducing an option to `allow anyone` pull packages from the package registry, no matter what is the project visibility.

## :fire: Problem

Due to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329253#note_1120283554, that option will only be applied to project-level endpoints.

This needs to be clearly documented.

## :fire_engine: Solution

Document the `allow anyone` option.

Document its limitations as listed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329253#note_1120283554.

In addition, document the limitations of this option: 
1. that this option does not work with the ~"Composer Repository".
1. this option does not have an impact on the ~"Conan Repository" search endpoint. (anonymous users will not be able to use `$ conan search`)

title: IssueFinder: Investigate BannedUser  performance
description:
With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/89051 we changed the way how issues created by banned users are filtered to ([src](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/67a40b4bad7724d47d7c2d868139e3aeee1c83af/app/models/issue.rb#L183))

```ruby
  scope :without_hidden, -> {
    if Feature.enabled?(:ban_user_feature_flag)
      where.not(author_id: Users::BannedUser.all.select(:user_id))
    else
      all
    end
  }
```

At the time it seemed unexpensive, but we now have > 30k banned users on `.com` potentially slowing down certain certain queries (like e.g. issue count). We should investigate if that assumption is true and if it is, whether there are better strategies to filter out these issues.

See this relevant discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383367#note_1182467577

cc/ @pshutsin @ahegyi @alexpooley

title: GitHub PR comment threads not imported correctly
description:
### Summary

In using the import from GitHub, comment threads are not correctly imported -- the behaviour seems nondeterministic.

### Steps to reproduce

We are finding this on all projects we import (projects are private in GitHub) that have comment threads in PRs.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Here's an example comment thread in GitHub

![image](/uploads/8a2c92a573cabb97652a3835c8aa6672/image.png)

In one import to GitLab it imports as this set of multiple comments ('Overview' screen)

On another import, it still doesn't associate the comment thread, but is different.

description:
## Problem

As we make changes to improve the performance of pipeline creation we need a set of SSoT metrics that we can monitor in order to evaluate the impacts of the changes.

## Dashboard

[Kibana Dashboard](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/dashboards#/view/5ecae940-6b52-11ed-85ed-e7557b0a598c?_g=(filters%3A!()%2CrefreshInterval%3A(pause%3A!t%2Cvalue%3A0)%2Ctime%3A(from%3Anow-7d%2Fd%2Cto%3Anow))) (being updated constantly)

## Data required

We need to have:
- average metrics
- possibly p95 and p99 metrics
- stacked times (p99 and average, at least) of more granular metrics about `Seed` and `Create` steps of the pipeline creation sequence.

title: Investigate indexing backup in sidekiq
description:
Starting on 2022-11-16 there have been consistent alerts for `gitlab_search_indexing_queue_backing_up` at the same time: 00:19 UTC every day (we do not get the alert on weekends due to the lower load). We need to find out what is causing the backups and resolve the issue.

Some observations:

* It feels too regular to be initiated by indexing documents via the web or API
* Only appears to be an issue for the incremental indexing queue. However, that could be because we do not get huge amounts of data indexed into the initial queue so maybe that's not really a symptom
* Happens every ~~week~~ day including weekends at 00:19 UTC

<details><summary>Grafana graph (check `ElasticSearch queue size`)</summary>

https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-global_search/stage-groups-global-search-group-dashboard?orgId=1&from=now-7d&to=now

![image](/uploads/7bc6285dd6798037f7bf4bd661422de4/image.png)

</details>

title: Java Spring Boot: Versioning
description:
### Goal

A versioning strategy which is reflected in the published artifacts.

### Implementation

See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9237+

Version using a MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH format. The `MAJOR` version is defined in `project.properties`. The script `build/buildtag.sh` calculates the version number to be used and places it in the `BUILDTAG` environment variable.
The environment variable is read in by the `build.gradle.kts` files and use as the version.

Only `main` and `prod-xxx` branches will have a version number. Other branches will use a default of `0.0.0`.

title: Java Spring Boot: Publish to staging and production
description:
### Goal

Jobs in the pipeline that publish the built executable to a staging registry, and promote from the staging registry to the production registry, and run tests to verify that the publishing is successful.

### Implementation

Note: testing the result of publication is best done by using the template, which is created in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383304+. Tests can use the template from the feature branch until it is merged.

- [x] Staging
    - [ ] Create a project for the staging registry
        - https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/package_registry/
        - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/api-fuzzing-src/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml#L265
        - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297525#group-and-project-settings
    - [x] Publish to Staging pipeline job
        - [x] Fetches built executable from pipeline artifacts and pushes to staging registry
    - [x] Run acceptance tests:
        - [x] Include template in pipeline
        - [x] Run included job
        - [x] Assert doc as artifact
- [x] Production
    - [x] Create a project for the production registry to mirror staging
    - [x] Publish to Production pipeline job
        - [ ] Promote executable from staging to production registry
        - [ ] Only on main branch
    - [x] Run acceptance tests
        - Probably all acceptance tests; although the majority should be redundant at that point after running in staging, they shouldn't take long to run, and they act as a final level of confidence in the release
    - [x] Tag git commit
        - [ ] Ensure this does not kick off a new pipeline
        - As soon as the artifact is promoted, or after tests finish?

title: Java Spring Boot: Initial Implementation
description:
### Goal

A Java executable which, given a path to a Spring Boot Executable Jar, will produce an OpenAPI document describing the endpoints in that jar, which is saved as a file.

### Criteria

This initial implementation will target the lowest versions we intend to support, which will make it easier to support later versions due to backward compatibility; or the easiest to implement scenario we intend to support where version doesn't apply.

* Java 8 (as the default Java version available on the runner)
* Spring Boot 2.0.9
* [Spring Boot Executable Jar](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/executable-jar.html#appendix.executable-jar.nested-jars.jar-structure)
* Built with Gradle + Spring Boot plugin
  * Although we intend to test artifacts built by both Gradle and Maven for completeness, the version of the build tool is not expected to be a significant variable. We should pick a stable version of each build tool and use it across all test artifacts.

### Implementation

- [ ] Java Executable  
See spike code at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/api-discovery-src/-/tree/spike-springdoc-offline
    - ~Read location of jar file from environment variable, include it in classpath~
        - For now we will be adding the target artifact to the classpath in the template
    - [x] Start a Spring context loading Spring Boot and SpringDoc configurations

title: Remove secrets from logs in reported places
description:
### Problem

API Security is often configured with authentication tokens needed to call operations during the scan phase. It has been found that the secret values can be found in the logs in three places.

1.  `./gl-api-security-worker-entry.log:19:2022-11-18 11:57:52 [DEB] API Security: Setting 'overrides_env' with value of '{"headers":{"Authorization":"Bearer glpat-secret_pat"}}' on app`
1. `./gl-api-security-scanner.log:26:11:58:13.159 [INF] <Peach.Web.Runner.Services.Overrides> Refreshing overrides from environmental variable: {"headers":{"Authorization":"Bearer glpat-secret_pat"}}`
1. `./gl-api-security-scanner.log:22:11:58:05.715 [INF] <Peach.Web.Controllers.Api.RunnerController> Create(CreateJob ...."{\"headers\":{\"Authorization\":\"Bearer glpat-secret_pat\"}}",....`

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383142

### Proposal

1. Modify the `Variable` definitions to include an `is_secret` parameter. When set, don't display masked value in the logs.
2. Don't display overrides values in log message
3. Don't dump all parameters to the `Create` call

title: Compare previous billed users count and new one from preview
description:
### Problem

If the group has an overage and adds a user that will **not** increase already existing billable members count we should **not** show the overage.

Currently we rely on API field `hasOverage` to show/hide the overage

### Proposal

Add one more field `willIncreaseOverage` that would compare current billed user count and the one from the preview. If the number will be increased return `true`, otherwise `false`.

title: Retry button if there are failed status checks
description:
This is a followup from the discussion in this thread https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8516#note_1173353507

> I feel like we should have a way to force a re-check without having to make a change. Like a button beside the check to re-run the check. We currently use something like that for site validation for DAST profiles. As a first iteration, that would make this a lot more useable when the checks are blocking an MR.

> Yes, we will need backend work. Outside of the 3 actions mentioned [in the doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/status_checks.html), we currently have no way of triggering the webhook that informs the external service to run a check, so we need a new API endpoint for it.

> Here is the [figma link to the designs](https://www.figma.com/file/zqEjEpLS0ggRsbUdzDrWkj/Retry-button-%5BGovern%2FCompliance%23383200%5D?node-id=24%3A7586&t=fyH8him9zvfP4o7n-1)

> Regarding the `Retry` button, we'll need to work with Foundations to make sure we're using the merge report framework correctly. For example, would you expect to see `Retry` on each individual failed check (the `GitBot` example [posted above](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8516#note_1175253079)), or should it only be on the top level (ie 2 failed status checks - Retry all failed checks)


~backend Create an API to retry the failed status check.

## Purposed Implementation Plan

weight: :two: 

1. Create post api `/api/v4/projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/status_checks/:check_id/retry`

###### Example curl 
```bash
curl --location --request POST 'curl --location --request POST 'http://BASE_URL//api/v4/projects/6/merge_requests/4/status_checks/1/retry' \
--header 'Authorization: ACCESS_TOKEN' \
--data-raw '''
```
2. User `merge_request.to_hook_data(current_user)` to generate current state payload
3. Async post this data payload to status checks url
4. Write Specs

  
~frontend A button to call the retry API from the MR widget

title: Simplify the signing commits popover
description:
With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97248 it's possible to sign commits using SSH keys. It's an opportunity to simplify the popover. (@mle thanks for the proposal!)

1. The check icon is larger than the icon size of 16x16 (https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-svgs/?q=\\\~check-sm)
   * Recommendation: Remove the icon
2. The word verified is used twice in this sentence but it is unclear why the "verified signature" is in bold.
   * Recommendation: Use the popover title for using bold
3. Commiter name and avatar is being displayed but this is the same as the avatar and name on the left
   * Recommendation: Remove the avatar and user details
4. The sentence wraps on two lines and could be rephrased to fit one line
   * Recommendation: Remove the word "more" and add a `.` to the sentence.
5. `Verified` badge does not match the badge styling for Pajamas.
   * Recommendation: Use Pajamas badge styling which is looks more like a pill
   * Variant: `Success`
6. `Unverified` badge does not match the badge styling for Pajamas.
   * Recommendation: Use Pajamas badge styling
   * Variant: `Neutral muted` 
7. The key label and key value should have `word-break: normal` and the key value should have `word-break: break-all` so that it can wrap

title: Print example CI config from Vault helper Rake task
description:
# Problem

The configuration to fetch Vault secrets using the `secrets` and `id_tokens` keywords is complex and misconfigurations are be difficult for developers to debug.

# Proposed solution

Have the `vault:configure` Rake task print an example configuration, pulling values from the developer's GDK config. Example:

```yaml
test_secrets:
  variables:
    VAULT_AUTH_PATH: gitlab
    VAULT_AUTH_ROLE: gitlab-test-role
    VAULT_SERVER_URL: http://<vault_ip_address>:8200  # generate this value from GDK config
  secrets:
    TEST_ID_TOKEN:
      id_token:
        aud: '<gdk_address>'  # generate this value from GDK config
    DATABASE_PASSWORD:
      vault: gitlab-test/db/password 
  script:
    - echo $DATABASE_PASSWORD
    - cat $DATABASE_PASSWORD

```

title: DAST API scanner includes Authorization header value in vulnerabilities
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Vulnerabilities created by DAST API scanner do not mask or remove the `Authorization` header values. This header is used for authenticating the scanner to the target application. The authentication tokens will be accessible to anyone who has access to the vulnerability. 

Example https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-security/appsec/dast-scan-4-fedramp/-/security/vulnerabilities/62832546

Even though it is recommended to run scans on non-production environments, authentication credentials are sensitive information and are recommended to be masked or removed from the vulnerability to prevent unintended leaks. There could be also cases where scans are run on production environments because of various compliance/certification requirements in which case this issue will lead to production credential leaks.

### Steps to reproduce

Run authenticated API scan and check the vulnerability report.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-security/appsec/dast-scan-4-fedramp/-/security/vulnerabilities/62832546

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Authentication credentials are included in the vulnerability.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Authentication credentials are not included in the vulnerability.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2022-11-17_at_15.12.58](/uploads/e62a4c99d33d7b78acf1370e6af3fe34/Screenshot_2022-11-17_at_15.12.58.png)

### Proposal

1. [X] Replace `Authorization` header value with `XXXXXXXXXX` (10 `X` characters)
1. [X] Replace in report vulnerability details
1. [x] Replace in Postman file generation
1. [x] Replace in Raw message zip file

Extend method used to reconstruct messages to support hiding secrets.

title: Add application admin setting to enable/disable migrating projects with GL Migration
description:
We are in the process of releasing migrating projects with GL Migration to open beta, see [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9285).

We should add an application admin setting to allow admins of self-managed instances to enable/disable migrating projects with GitLab Migration in admin settings.

This will be useful also in the future, when we enable migrating only projects.

We plan to also present an option for user in UI, if they want to include projects in particular group migration or not - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383332+.

### Proposed solution
- [ ] migrating projects with GL Migration should be **disabled** by default on SM
- [ ] documentation update
- [ ] migrating projects both from UI and via API with GL Migration disabled when toggle is off
- [ ] if the toggle is off and user tries to migrate via API they should get a informative feedback

### Technical details
1. Db migration to add new setting in `applications_settings`
1. Update controllers & API to respect the new setting

### Documentation

As we will have two toggles, it's important that we describe and document them well.

There will be 4 scenarios:

1. :white_check_mark: GLM all (groups & projects)
:white_check_mark: GLM projects only

2. :white_check_mark: GLM all (groups & projects)
:x: GLM projects only

3. :x: GLM all (groups & projects)
:x: GLM projects only

4. :x: GLM all (groups & projects)
:white_check_mark: GLM projects only

The last scenario is not be possible at the moment, and this can be confusing to user. This needs to be documented. In the future iteration we could disallow such choice and give feedback to user in UI.

#### Docs to update

- [ ] The UI part will be at: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/import/index.html
- [ ] The REST API part will be at: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/settings.html

title: [GitLab Migration] Exported relations fail to download if stored in S3 object storage
description:
Whenever GitLab Migration runs and tried to download exported relations from source & source has exported relations stored in AWS S3 - the importer fails to download with the 403 error.

This is happening because in `BulkImports::FileDownloadService` we first perform a `HEAD` request to get information about the file, run validations. And AWS S3 does not support HEAD requests to the pre-signed URLs it generates for the exported relations to be accessed, only GET. 

```ruby
curl --head --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: TOKEN" "http://gdk.test:3000/api/v4/groups/144/export_relations/download?relation=labels" -L --output -
HTTP/1.1 303 See Other

Location: http://127.0.0.1:9000/uploads/bulk_imports/export_upload/export_file/2962/labels.ndjson.gz?X-Amz-Expires=600&X-Amz-Date=20221117T101025Z&X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=minio%2F20221117%2Fgdk%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&X-Amz-Signature=fbe75f423f9bed0f84411bef3b82a823633cc892cdc89e27da072e62e778b542

HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 0
```

### Potential fixes

1. Skip these validations if file is stored in S3
1. Can we use GET with `stream_body: true` to get hold of headers and skip downloading body to simulate HEAD request?
2. Use GET but this makes us download the file twice, so let's not do that :smile:

epic.title: 🐞 GitLab Migration bugs

title: Initialize product analytics stack via GraphQL mutation
description:
## Overview

Currently the only way to initialize the product analytics stack for a project is to manually call the `ProductAnalytics::InitializeStackService` service from the rails console.

We need a way for an API consumer to trigger the service idempotently.

## Implementation plan

* Before enqueuing the stack initialization worker, populate a redis key `project_{ID}_product_analytics_stack_initializing = true`. Include an expiry.
* On completion (or failure) delete the redis key.
* Create graphql mutation to execute `InitializeStackService`. Returns the state of the analytics stack. (Enqueued or error)

title: Add ability to associate customizable roles with static roles via API
description:
2 approaches could work:

### Option 1
First approach would be similar to: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370090; we would create entirely new API endpoints that find custom role and associate it with an existing static role. Something like:

`PATCH/PUT /groups/:id/member_roles` where you would pass a `user` and `namespace` as params and it would find the `member` record for that `user` + `namespace` and associate it with the `member_role`

### Option 2

Second approach would be update the [existing API endpoints](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/members.html#edit-a-member-of-a-group-or-project) `PUT /groups/:id/members/:user_id` and `PUT /projects/:id/members/:user_id` so that they can be used to update a member record and add a `member_role_id`.

Note: Please add the ability to pass the Users to be assigned the role as a list. We have an early adopter who would like to assign this to 800 users. Doing it 1 by 1 is not scalable.

title: Add flag for reduced security finding data set
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

As we work on https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8910+, we will not be needing as much data to be sent to the pipeline security tab. We would only need to be sending data that the listing needs as the modal would be pulling data using the new GraphQL query. This data reduction should be handled with a flag sent in the request for full or partial data, that way current users won't be disrupted.

Call: api/v4/projects/20/vulnerability_findings?pipeline_id=<pipeline ID>&scope=dismissed

We will also need to work with GitLab teams that use the existing calls.

UPDATE 11/30: After further analysis, only the confidence field can be removed from the finding data that won't break the Pipeline Security Tab.

### Existing Fields

```
id
report_type
name
severity
confidence
scanner
  external_id
  name
  vendor
identifiers
  external_type
  external_id
  name
  url
project_fingerprint
uuid
create_jira_issue_url
false_positive
create_vulnerability_feedback_issue_path
create_vulnerability_feedback_merge_request_path
create_vulnerability_feedback_dismissal_path
project
  id
  name
  full_path
  full_name
dismissal_feedback
issue_feedback
merge_request_feedback
description
links
location
  file
  start_line
  class
  method
remediations
  null
solution
evidence
request
response
evidence_source
supporting_messages
assets
details
state
scan
  type
  status
  start_time
  end_time
blob_path
```

title: Correct the colors of the trend indicators in the DORA metrics comparative view
description:
Currently, the trend icons are styled with the green colour when a metric increases and with red when it decreases. However, some metrics are improved when the value decreases. For example, a reduction in lead time for changes should be green, not red because it’s a positive change.

Current comparative table:

![image](/uploads/c698d6555af406f34a51a2a20379c979/image.png)

The following metrics should be "reversed"*:
* Lead time for changes
* Time to restore service
* Change failure rate

*meaning that an increase is negative (red) and a decrease is positive (green)

title: RPM: non working aspects
description:
## :fire: Problem

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371959+, I helped verifying that pulling an RPM package was working.

At that time, I [noticed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371959#note_1172605609) several aspects as non working using this branch: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/372737-demo

1. For some reason, the [authentication](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/2f74b1b06a93cfcc2e023979569615f886146f37/lib/api/rpm_project_packages.rb#L18-20) was not working.
1. The upload was done as a multipart upload. This has the following downsides:
   * It is a `POST` multipart upload which makes the curl command to use more verbose.
   * It is _not_ using the workhorse assisted upload [part](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/2f74b1b06a93cfcc2e023979569615f886146f37/workhorse/internal/upstream/routes.go#L292).
   * The upload endpoint absolutely needs to validate that workhorse 
1. The `repomd.xml` file was not referencing the right path for each xml file.
1. `pkgid` was empty and not used through the different xml files.

## :fire_engine: Solutions

Here are my suggestions for each issue:

1. Check why the authentication is not working. It should work, that could is being used in other package formats.
1. Since we do have the [freedom](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/296785#note_1070086773) (Section `Uploading a package`) to choose how to upload files, let's use a very simple form: a `PUT` body upload. This is already used by the Generic package registry for example.
1. Use the Grape generated helper functions to get the proper path.
1. It seems that we have the choice of the digest used here, so use `sha256` everywhere and use the `sha256` of the package file as the `pkgid`.
